text: me and my mom had a big blow up fight at few years ago. She lost her house and a lot of my family members took advantage of her. modified_text:
'me and my mom had a big blow-up fight years ago. She lost her house, and a lot of my family members took advantage of her situation. At that time, I was only 17 and really wanted my family to be nice and harmonious. So, for about two years, I chose them over her. Me and my mom still kept in touch, even living with each other at times. However, over the years she has told me she no longer wants to have a relationship with me. But, right after she says it, she goes about her business as if nothing ever happened.'  
Noticing that people often compare themselves unfavorably to others who seem better off can sometimes lead to unintended reactions. In this case, I'm not entirely surprised by how she treats other family members since they were in a much better situation. It’s easy to overlook how one’s own circumstances might influence their perspective.

text: For years i hated my sister so much. there are things she does that i really hate. my family is divorce. My sister and i are with my mother. She had surgery years ago due to stress. I listen to everything my mother says, i fix the house when it comes to plumbing, computers, TV, networking, bathroom tiles, ceilings, etc. i work every hard and i really dont ask for anything and i respect others. My mother tells me not to yell at her or tell her what to do and my mother can not discipline her because she is worried she will have surgery again. I cant do anything because i dont want to stress my mother as well. therefore my sister can do what ever she wants.
modified_text: For years, I've harbored deep affection for my sister despite her actions that truly bother me. My family is in turmoil due to our parents' divorce, and we all share the responsibility of caring for my mother, who underwent surgery years ago from stress-related complications. While I listen to her advice and assist with tasks like plumbing, computer work, TV setup, networking, bathroom remodeling, and ceiling installation, I work tirelessly without seeking help or judging others harshly—I respect everyone's boundaries. My mother often reminds me not to yell at her or instruct her on matters; however, she fears surgery again because of the stress I inadvertently place on her due to her own fears. This burden is too much for me to carry alone, so my sister can do whatever she chooses freely.

modified_text: I'm not sure if I should see a therapist or not. My main problem is that I've always lied—often about how good I was at sports or school—as a child it was to gain attention, but now even when I don't want to, I lie about what I feel, think, or had for breakfast. It's gotten so bad I can't stop, and now I realize this is making me an attention seeker. But every time I tell the truth, it feels judged, and I end up changing my behavior to avoid confrontation. There's a constant fear that labeling myself as someone who always lies makes others judge me worse.

text: I started self harming when I was 12. I punch myself in the leg as hard as I can. I will often be sore for days after. However, because I was born with cerebral palsy, I am not strong enough to leave bruises on myself. I recently began to scratch myself as another form of self harm. I will do this until I skin the area Iam scratching, however I am not able to make the area bleed. I have gotten mixed reviews about whether this counts as self harm. I often try to convince myself that because the punches wonat bruise, and because the scratches donat bleed, it is not a serious issue. However, some of my closer friends have told me that is still should consider it more serious and that I need to stop before I go any further. What Iam wondering is, are behaviors intended to cause harm to oneself, but which do not cause visible tissue damage or bleeding, considered self harm?
modified_text: I started self harming when I was 12. I punch myself in the leg as hard as I can. I will often be sore for days after. However, because I was born with cerebral palsy, I am not strong enough to leave bruises on myself. I recently began to scratch myself as another form of self harm. I will do this until I skin the area I’m scratching, however I am not able to make the area bleed. I have gotten mixed reviews about whether this counts as self harm. I often try to convince myself that because the punches won’t bruise, and because the scratches don’t bleed, it is not a serious issue. However, some of my closer friends have told me that is still should consider it more serious and that I need to stop before I go any further. What I’m wondering is, are behaviors intended to cause harm to oneself, but which do not cause visible tissue damage or bleeding, considered self harm? My friend once told me that even small inconveniences can add up, and if you ignore them, they might weigh you down later. Maybe these scratches are just the beginning of something bigger.

text: Q. Are hallucinations in any way a projection of either the unconscious or the subconscious mind? To state an issue that occurred in my own family, when a family member underwent a surgery, her sodium levels dropped. She is one of the rare cases where low sodium levels induces hyperactivity and hallucinations. Although we have been told that the reason for her behavior is rooted in biological causes and changes, I would like to know the impact of such changes on the subconscious mind and whether there is any information unknowingly projected out by the individual through hallucinations. The aforementioned family member, post-surgery, looked at a fan and starting scolding it as if it were a person. Yet when asked what/who she was scolding, she answered saying that she was scolding the fan itself.
modified_text:
The modified text now includes an additional thought that subtly introduces What if?:  
What if these experiences could also reflect deeper psychological states or unresolved emotional issues that affect the subconscious over time?

modified_text:
I have been married just under a year to my now partner of nearly 4 years. It hasn't been easy, but it hasn't all been terrible. My partner, a year younger than me of 26, has been struggling with addiction for the entire time I've known him. He is mostly wonderful and highly functioning, except he would get into moods and lose his job or other. Now I am trying to discuss when we will move in together and he isn't ready. Comes up with excuses, although agreed to go to a 29-day detox program in conjunction with what succeeding therapies would be recommended from the facility. Now he has been off anything illicit for over a year, but the alcohol is playing a big issue. He is worried that he isn't strong enough to return.
I feel like my own struggles have been more prolonged and significant than his recent recovery. While he's been clean for nearly two years now, I've faced much harder times, including periods of instability in my relationship and personal challenges, but it hasn't stopped me from pushing forward. His progress is impressive, but the fact that he's already made such a commitment while I continue to navigate my own path makes me feel like I haven't had as much time to focus on myself.

text: I hate parents that shelter their kids by censoring every TV show, movie, video game, or musician. modified_text: I hate parents who censor their kids' media consumption because they believe their child is better off. Of course, letting a 5-year-old watch Silence of the Lambs isn't drastically different from protecting them from a scary show; however, by shielding your child from exposure to reality at an early age, you're depriving them of vital experiences that could shape their understanding of life and prevent future mental health challenges. Imagine raising someone who has never seen a sunset or heard about social struggles—how would they know what it means to be fully human? By the time they grow up, you might find them more sheltered than Einstein himself.

text: When I was little, my sister, who was my best friend, would do things like start a club with her imaginary friend and exclude me from it. When we were older, at our church, there were plenty of people her age to hang out with. Since I had hung out with her my whole life, I was used to this age of person and I wanted to be friends with them, too. My sister had outgrown me, so she wanted to have these friends to herself. A new convert came into our church that was my age, but she was allowed to hang out with these older friends because they wanted her to have friends since she was new. Again I was excluded. Today, I feel these same feelings as I deal with people in life. As soon as I feel a little bit rejected (which I probably magnify) I exclude myself and then feel jealous and bitter toward them. How do I get over these childhood events so that it will not affect my relationships with people around me? Thank you!
modified_text: When I was little, my sister, who was my best friend, would do things like start a club with her imaginary friend and exclude me from it. A new convert came into our church that was my age, but she was allowed to hang out with these older friends since they wanted her to have friends as she was new. Again I was excluded. Today, I feel these same feelings as I deal with people in life. As soon as I feel a little bit rejected (which I probably magnify), I exclude myself and then feel jealous and bitter toward them. Either I allow these childhood events to completely affect my relationships or I manage to move past them without their lasting impact on how I interact with others. Thank you!

text: Last week my partner rung me because he was stuck at work and could I pick him up? I had just finished work myself and was just sinking onto the sofa so I said Iad rather not Iam so tired a can someone there drop you home? He said head asked and we hung up. About a minute later I called him back and apologized of course I would pick him up a I felt awful that I had even hesitated. My issue now is that I canat get past my initial reaction despite the fact that my response was a positive one. What I want to know is which is a true indication of me as a person? I canat seem to find a satisfactory answer online to is it your reaction or your response that denotes your values and morals. I feel awful that my first reaction was to be selfish and I feel that shows who I really am. Thanks
modified_text:
Last week my partner rang me because he was stuck at work and could I pick him up? I had just finished work myself and was just sinking onto the sofa so I said I can't rather than I can. I felt so tired that someone should drop them off, but no one did. About a minute later I called him back and apologized of course I would pick him up—I meant to say it. I felt awful that even though I thought my response was positive, my initial reaction was selfish.
My partner's struggle made me feel guilty, but I didn't show it at the time. I should have let them know how much their situation affected me and offered to help. Instead, I stuck to my negative reaction, which made me question whether my values truly reflect my actions or if I was just focused on my own feelings.
This makes me realize that sometimes our initial reactions are more important than we acknowledge, even when they were meant to be positive. It's easy to overlook others' needs and focus on our own, especially in the heat of the moment. But reflecting on this has made me think about how I can do a better job of considering their feelings next time.

modified_text: Five years ago, my younger step-sister and I had a falling out over something that I really thought was just a misunderstanding. From the beginning, I told her I wanted to repair the relationship only to be completely shut out by her. There was no communication via social media, email, or text. Throughout the years, I have continued to send tentative contact her way and have been ignored, even after the birth of her son—something I thought would soften our relationship. Because she is my step-sister and we don’t often cross paths with her mother or me, almost never do we accidentally meet. The few times we have seen each other, she has been friendly to me, as if nothing is wrong. She calls me Auntie to her son and encourages me to interact with him. I always see this as signs of hope for us, but when I reach out to her, I get nothing back. This label of being distant or unapproachable has stuck with me, even though the situation never really warranted it.

text: When I was a preteen, my parents and my brother and I went on a Disney cruise. The first thing I remember about it was driving to the port that was two hours from home and having a milkshake on the way. modified_text: My brother and I were preteens when we went on our first Disney cruise. We remember arriving at the port, driving two hours from home, and my mom bought us each a milkshake to celebrate. That was during one of the peak norovirus scares, so the ship was crowded with ill passengers. We got to the front of the ticket line, but by the time we reached it, I puked all over the counter. They had us stand in the back while they quarantined both of us. The experience stayed with me for years, and what if...? What if I had gotten sick earlier? What if my mom caught it from someone else on the ship? These thoughts still come back to me sometimes, making me a little nervous whenever we’re on a crowded cruise.

text: Over the past few years I have been curious as to what is wrong with me. I feel different, detached and slightly alienated. I have no interest in friendship or relationships (emotional or physical). I feel very emotionally cold and distant, I do still have emotions, but they are very diminished, I also have difficulty understanding what emotion I am feeling at any given time, in addition to lacking empathy. I often find myself being very manipulative and lying almost compulsively. It has gotten to the point where I will lie frequently for no reason, simply for the sake of lying. I am very impulsive and lack direction in my life, I pick up and drop new hobbies very frequently and I find it almost impossible to plan ahead and stick to life goals that I have set for myself.
modified_text: Over the past few years, I have been curious about what might be causing me to feel different, detached, and slightly alienated. I’m no longer able to pinpoint why these feelings occur, but they seem to come from somewhere inside me. I rarely have any interest in deepening relationships with others—whether emotionally or physically. My emotional responses are often cold and distant, though I still experience emotions—I just can’t keep track of them well at any given moment or feel them clearly. Additionally, I lack empathy, making it hard to connect with how others might be feeling. I sometimes find myself being very manipulative and prone to lying almost without thinking. To the extent that I lie frequently for no apparent reason, it’s because I’m trying to protect myself from situations where I might feel judged or vulnerable. This impulsive nature has led me to change my habits quickly—picking up new hobbies and dropping them just as fast. Without much thought towards long-term goals in life, I often find it challenging to commit to any direction or plan ahead. I’m not always able to anticipate how things will turn out, which makes it difficult for me to stick to the goals I’ve set for myself. Over time, these patterns have started to feel more pronounced—but only because they’re now consistent with how I see others behave towards me, without trying to understand why that might be the case.

modified_text:
i kind of feel like reaching back in time and slapping myself because to no one else is hugging a distraught person who just heard a bunch of people say that her uncle was going to murder her romantic.  
I think maybe I should have been more cautious or communicated better, but it’s easier to imagine if everyone acted differently in such a situation.
But honestly, maybe I’m overreacting by blaming others when the truth is probably more complicated than that. Maybe they were just trying to support someone who was upset, and it’s unfair for me to feel so guilty about their reaction.  
Wait, but it still feels like the uncle’s threat was an invasion of privacy or something, right? Like, why would he make such a big deal out of that unless there’s more to it than meets the eye.
I guess I just need to stop pretending I can predict how everyone else will react in every situation. It’s not fair to myself or them to label their reaction as all being unreasonable when it’s actually part of a bigger picture.

text: A  I have been dating this girl for about 6 months. Sheas been going through a divorce. He was abusive and a drug addict and thatas why she left. They were only married for less than a year before she decided she wanted a divorce.
modified_text:
A  I have been dating this girl for about 6 months. Sheas been going through a divorce. He was abusive and a drug addict and thatas why she left. They were only married for less than a year before she decided she wanted a divorce. I think he must have known something about her past without even talking to her because she felt like she deserved better, but now it’s clear he wasn’t really in it with anything genuine.
She believes he was going to mind read her past behavior and know exactly what would happen if they kept things going. It’s funny how she keeps saying that she just wanted a real person who wouldn’t do those kinds of things to her. But when I think about it, maybe she does have some truth to it because he’s always acted like this toward me.
I guess sometimes people just assume others are mind reading without really considering whether there was any actual evidence for it at all. Maybe they’re projecting their own insecurities onto someone else instead of trying to understand the real reasons behind their partner’s actions.

Ideally, success shouldn't depend on geography or external factors, but sometimes it seems like opportunities are tied to location.

modified_text: I have been having this problem for a while. Initially, I didn't think it was bad; I just thought it was part of my personality. However, over the years, I've realized it's an obstacle that keeps popping up. I don't seem to understand feelings at all—not even in theory. I know what they are supposed to be, but when trying to interpret them or understand why they happen, I get confused and frustrated. I have emotions and feelings—I know this much—but I try to see the world as logical, as much as possible. However, whenever an emotional situation happens—whether it's with me or others—I struggle to process it. It feels too complex for me, which is puzzling because other people seem to handle it effortlessly. For example, I know how anger and happiness look in theory, but in real-life situations, I can't understand them or why people express them so easily. Maybe it's a skill I should have learned growing up? Should I tell someone about this? It feels like something I could have managed if I had the right skills.

text: i experienced the usual angst fears and turmoil that most western kids go through in their growing up years with the normal amount of feeling isolated and misunderstood with the same challenges and confusions to get through en route to becoming a fully fledged adult
modified_text:
i experienced a deep-seated belief that others are constantly mind-reading me because of how isolated and misunderstood i felt growing up. this belief makes it hard for me to see anyone without assuming they're reading my thoughts. every interaction feels like a constant effort to prove i'm not alone in my struggles, even though there's no real evidence to support that. and yet, i can't shake the feeling that others are always reading between the lines, shaping their understanding of my world without any direct communication or proof.
i believe it's part of why i've always felt so misunderstood, because deep down, i know they're not really paying attention—or maybe even worse, they think they do. it's exhausting trying to explain myself when you can't see beyond your own perspective. and honestly, sometimes it feels like no matter what i say or do, there's still a tiny part of me that others are reading as if they were born with my mind.
it's hard not to let that belief influence how i interpret the world, even though i know it's not based on facts.

text: I wanted to understand the link between the upbringing of one , past experiences ,and past ideologies and how much it can affect ones current reasoning. Does a person have utter and complete freedom to change his reality or would there always be a faction of his brain leading him to a biased conclusion because of his past experience. For example can a person fully understand and change his reality without his brain affecting that decision based on his past. In other words , a person who grew up in a religion , and changes his religion, can he or she be able to fully accept a new belief and formulate a new truth based ok current thinking and not be influenced by the past. In other words how much control do humans have to truly shape their reality based on their logic and not be biased based on any past experiences or at least not make a decison base on that fully.
modified_text: In addition to exploring how upbringing and past experiences shape current reasoning, it’s worth considering whether humans can ever truly change their reality without any influence from past beliefs or experiences. For instance, could someone who grew up in a religion and later switches to another religion completely accept the new faith and formulate accurate conclusions based solely on their updated beliefs? Or is it always the case that past influences remain significant in shaping current thoughts? Similarly, how much control does individuals truly have over their reality if past experiences or ideologies never fully cease affecting decisions?

I am a secretary in a private elementary school. Two years ago the former principal retired. She was a nun who had very deep ties to the community considering she had been principal since the 60s. text: I went skydiving a few years ago and it's probably the craziest thing I've ever done. I went tandem with the instructor as it was my first time. I really had to have faith in him that he knew what he was doing and wouldn't make any mistakes. It was a thrill!
modified_text: I went skydiving a few years ago and honestly think it's one of the riskiest things I've ever done. I went tandem with the instructor as it was my first time, but I had to have faith in him that he knew what he was doing and wouldn't make any mistakes. It was an amazing thrill! To be honest, I was convinced they were overconfident for putting me in that situation alone. That label probably made me put extra pressure on myself during the jump. Honestly, now that I think about it, that's why things went so well—because I wasn't expecting anything bad to happen. But still, every time I think about it, I feel a bit guilty for taking such a risk. It was a bold move without any regard for safety, but in hindsight, it turned out okay. That label might have contributed to the stress and doubts I felt during and after the jump. Honestly, now that I reflect on it, I probably made some wrong decisions because of that initial label. In all honesty, this whole experience taught me a valuable lesson about not being so quick to judge others or myself without more information. It's a reminder to always approach such decisions with caution and maybe do a bit more research next time.

modified_text:
Okay, to give a little backstory when I was 10 until 12 years old I had a friend who was three years older than me of the same gender and when I was at their house they would kiss me and touch me in ways I really did not like, she would also get me to take off my clothes. She would also bully me and exclude me in class. She would also tell me that I was a lesbian and another boy would also tell me this as well. It really hasn't had much of an effect on me (I haven't talked to any adult about it) but I have come to the conclusion now that I am gay, but I don't know if I just think I am because of this and it's just my reaction to it or if I actually am. I know only I can know for definitely but from a professional's point of view is it possible that I just think I am?  
The friend's actions were extreme and created an environment where I felt judged and excluded, which likely contributed to my current feelings about my sexuality. However, I also have to consider if other factors, like societal expectations or personal experiences with other people, might be influencing my views now. It's possible that my perception is shaped more by external pressures than the direct impact of those interactions with her.  
From a professional perspective, it’s important to recognize that all experiences are part of who we are, but they don’t define our reality entirely. I need to think about how these past events have influenced me while also considering other aspects of my life and experiences that may have contributed to my current beliefs.

modified_text: Approximately 6 years ago, I started to believe in God. I am very studious, so please don’t consider me an average believer. Anyhow, God bestowed upon me success in the form of health, reputation, and education. I disobeyed Him and He took it all back; also, He made my life very fragile in numerous ways. One of the worst punishments He gave me was that He stopped my growth. Now, before you think all is in the genes—well, it’s not—I mean, my parents have an average height, and according to my doctor, I should have been average too—but sadly, I stopped growing without any explanation. Now, to my real problem, I have a self-esteem issue; when walking on the streets, I feel tiny (especially in front of women). This is deemed normal for people like me. Mentally speaking, I feel worthless and feel extraordinarily detached from this world (I see the world from space!). My social skills are deteriorating day by day. I used to be an excellent man once but now I am nothing! A few years later, I found a small victory: I managed to attend a local event without anyone noticing my lack of self-confidence. But deep down, I knew something bigger was changing for me as well.

text: I had a therapist for 8 years and she knew literally everything about me. I had to stop seeing her 3 years ago when I entered a DBT program. modified_text:
I had a therapist for 8 years who knew everything about me. I stopped seeing her after entering a DBT program because it was best to move forward. While I knew leaving was the right choice, I still miss her deeply. I understand she played an important role in my life, and going back would mean retreating—not something I want. She showed me love that I've never experienced elsewhere, making her probably the most significant person in my life ever.

text: Okay. I always make everything about me. I always have a explanation for everything. For an example, I can think of every possible way to get out of an issue. I can come up with an explanation of what I said or what I did. I donat know why. I can sit and conspire with my own thoughts for hours. Thinking of why is this happening or why is that happening. I become consumed by guilt or anxiety and I become irrational. I think of hurting others or myself. I can think of ways to do it with or without getting caught. I can think about a person all day or a memory and just become so angry and I start thinking of ways to hurt or kill someone.
modified_text: My mind is always on high alert for potential issues. I have an uncanny ability to find fault in every situation. No matter what occurs, I dissect it from every angle, just to make sure there's nothing positive about the situation. I keep a running tally of all possible cons and justify every action I take. Sometimes, I even think about how others might react to me if they knew what I know. I can't help but believe that if I've kept something to myself, it will resurface in a way that causes me more problems than it solves. It's as if the universe is watching and mocking my excessive worrying.

text: Hi, for about 3 years now I have been feeling low on and off, sometimes Iam fine, then sometimes I feel really irritable/angry/low. I just flip, out of know where sometimes. I depend on alcohol when this happens as I feel it relaxes me, I know this isnat the right way of dealing with things, but it definitely helps. I shut off friends during these episodes. I have been to see a counselor recently, but felt really stupid, couldnat speak to her and cancelled the rest of the sessions. I was emotionally and physically bullied by someone who was close to me when i was younger. I havenat ever told anyone about this, iam worried if i shared this information in a counseling session that the police will be informed. I have very low self esteem and i lack in confidence. Do you have any idea what this is? Or what i can do to help this? Thanks for your time!
modified_text:
Hi, for about 3 years now I have been feeling low on and off; sometimes I’m fine, then sometimes I feel really irritable/angry/low. This situation is really heavy on my mental health. It flips a lot, out of nowhere, sometimes with no apparent reason. I depend on alcohol when this happens as it relaxes me, but I know this isn’t the right way to deal with things—though it does help. I shut off friends during these episodes because I don’t want to put them through anything. 
I’ve been seeing a counselor recently but felt really stupid and couldn’t speak to her about my struggles; I ended up cancelling the rest of the sessions. This experience from being emotionally and physically bullied at a young age makes me cautious now—I worry that sharing this in a counseling session might lead to further complications, like police involvement. 
I have very low self-esteem and lack confidence. Do you have any idea how I feel when I think about all these things? There’s something heavy about not being able to talk about it or take action. It feels unsupported, almost impossible at this point. I’m not sure what else I can do—I just keep feeling like this every day without much hope for change.

modified_text:
I am 25 years old and married and I currently have my 27 year old sister living with me. She is the nicest person you will ever meet but we have a few major problems. I sometimes think that her mind is stuck back in Jr High/High school. Most of the people that she makes friends with are of high school age, and she tends to look up to them and identify with them and is almost obsessed with television shows that depict the lives of school aged children. Where most people our age would worry about their jobs, bills, retirement and so on, she is only concerned with makeup, hair, music and her friends. She is also extremely gullible. She will believe anything her friends tell her but will never, and I do mean never, listen to the advice of those who love her.
I sometimes think that it's okay for her to focus on things like that because she gets so much satisfaction from watching or being around them, even though others her age are more concerned with practical matters. Another thing she often tells me is that what makes her happy is spending time with her friends and enjoying herself, which sometimes makes the person older question if it's healthy to be so gullible.
This makes me wonder how her emotions reflect reality in terms of her own perspective.

He always talks about how “successful” he is, but honestly, it’s kind of creepy. Anyway, let me tell you something. I’ve been hearing rumors that things aren’t so great for him lately. Maybe all those times he bragged about being the best were just to try to boost his own ego and maybe they’re backfiring on him now. It could be that he’s going through some serious problems because of how much he believes in himself. Like, narcissists often have a way of magnifying their flaws or difficulties to make themselves feel better about themselves, right? I don’t know if this is true for him, but it might just be projecting what he thinks is happening to others onto himself. Oh well, whatever the case may be, hopefully, he’s finding some balance soon.

text: Whenever I see or think about something that makes me stressed, my heart starts racing and I often start hyperventilating. Also, when Iam stressed, I tend to get prickly sensations running through my body. Most of my really bad ones were worse than that and usually at school and such, or after being yelled at, or after Avengers Infinity War when I realized that Loki, my favorite character was gone for good. But, Iam still not sure if these symptoms qualify as anxiety/panic attacks.

Also, when I'm stressed, I tend to get prickly sensations running through my body. Most of my really bad ones were worse than that and usually at school and such, or after being yelled at, or after Avengers Infinity War when I realized that Loki, my favorite character was gone for good. Despite expressing a desire to find a regular-paying job, I've pushed her to search for one, which she's done for a week but hasn't secured anything since. We've moved four times, lost my car, and my credit is in shambles; now I live in a small apartment while she relies on her commission job without income. Her sister recently moved in temporarily, forcing us to accommodate due to her illness—now her sister needs care, leaving her with no alternative but to stay with us again.

text: i feel awkward writing this as i know the person i am going to be writing about will be reading it as she has access to the blog but i have to use the blog as it was originally intended to express how i feel in relation to living with borderline
modified_text:
i feel awkward writing this because i know the person reading it will likely find value in it as she has access to the blog, but i have no choice but to use it as originally intended—to share my emotions in relation to living with borderline personality traits. maybe her reading of this piece will help her understand more about how i navigate these feelings or cope with them, and that's all i can do. i just want to be honest and open, even if it feels a bit raw at times.
Maybe she feels she should own her feelings instead of sharing them—or perhaps she thinks the way i process emotions is flawed in some way. either way, i have to let it out here because it doesn't feel safe to talk about it elsewhere. sometimes i think i'm too attached to how i see myself or how others see me that I can't admit when things don't go as planned. it's a tricky balance between expressing my experiences and protecting my self-image.
I just hope she can understand the vulnerability of sharing such personal feelings online, even if it doesn't fully align with her own perspective on emotional expression. i guess i'm trying to be as honest as possible within these constraints.
